did.unittitle: Transport Workers Union of America Oral History Collection
did.abstract:
The Transport Workers Union was founded in 1934. The union represented transportation workers in both the public and private sectors. Its New York City-based Local 100 was its largest and was particularly active. Local 100 unionized the city's independent subway companies, and when New York City purchased the BMT and IRT lines in 1940, the majority of its members became city employees. While it had close ties with the Communist Party in it's early days, by the end of the 1940s these ties were severed and the far left was purged. Still, the union was one of the last holdouts against the Congress of Industrial Organizations' merger with the American Federation of Labor in 1955. Union president Mike Quill cast a long shadow over the union's activities from his election in 1935 until his death in 1966.
The collection consists of 15 interviews with officers, members, and staff of the Transport Workers Union. Subjects discussed mainly concern TWU history in the New York City area, but there are some references to union politics and activity on the national level. There is also one cassette of songs of the TWU.

bioghist.head: Historical/Biographical Note
bioghist.p: The Transport Workers Union Oral History Collection was initiated by Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives staff member Brenda Parnes in 1985 to fill gaps in documentation as she processed the papers of the union. The interviews were conducted by Parnes and Joseph Doyle from 1986-1988, then continued by Gail Malmgreen from 1990.

Founded in 1934 by Irish immigrants, the TWU was initially supported by the Communist Party, which provided funds, an office, and organizing assistance. In 1935, the charismatic Michael J. Quill was elected president of the union, an office he held until his death in 1966.
The largest and often the most turbulent of the TWU's locals was Local 100, which encompassed transit workers on the New York City municipal subway and bus systems, as well as employees of most of the private bus companies in the New York area. The Depression brought transit workers lower wages and long hours of work, as many as 12 hours a day, seven days a week. Unionization was only the first step toward achieving a more just and equitable workplace. As early as 1937, Local 100 won recognition elections on the BMT, IRT, the 3rd Avenue Railway, the 5th Avenue Coach Company, the NYC Omnibus Corporation, and several taxi companies. The contracts between the companies and the TWU provided for a closed shop, wage increases, paid vacations, and job security.

The early gains won in New York were overshadowed by the specter of the unification issue. New York City had financed the construction of its transit system, then leased the BMT and IRT lines to private managements. In 1932, the city began operating the Independent Subway System. In 1940 the City purchased the privately run BMT and IRT lines and joined them with the IND, creating one unified subway and elevated transit system. From this point on, the TWU in New York was largely a public-employee union, its fate intimately tied to the fates of various city administrations. Local 100 pressed for a five-day, forty-hour week with no reduction in pay. After a period of uneasy wartime cooperation with Mayor LaGuardia, the union struggled to hammer out a working partnership with a succession of democratic mayors. During this period, Quill broke from his Communist allies. In the years 1948-1949, the TWU was purged of left-wingers.

By 1950 the TWU had organized transit workers throughout the nation and in Puerto Rico and had chartered more than 100 locals. Among the post-World War II achievements was the reinstatement of returning veterans and improved wages, benefits, and working conditions. The union also maintained a lively program of services to members, including sports teams, theatrical groups, choral singing, annual outings, and classes open to members' families.

Something of a maverick union, Quill's TWU was the only international to hold out against the merger of the CIO with the AFL in 1955. In the same period, the union found itself in the vanguard of civil rights struggles within the Southern labor movement. It also launched vigorous organizing drives in both rail transport and the burgeoning airlines industry. Both the pace and tone of TWU activity moderated somewhat after Quill's death, in the wake of the brief but bitter NYC transit strike of 1966.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The collection consists of 15 interviews with officers, members, and staff of the Transport Workers Union, including Shirley Garry Quill, Maurice Forge, and Gerald O'Reilly. The subject matter mainly concerns TWU history in the New York City area, but there are some references to union politics and activity on the national level. There is also one cassette of songs of the TWU.

phystech.head: Audiovisual Access Policies and Procedures
phystech.p: Audiovisual materials have not been preserved and may not be available to researchers. Materials not yet digitized will need to have access copies made before they can be used. To request an access copy, or if you are unsure if an item has been digitized, please contact tamiment.wagner@nyu.edu with the collection name, collection number, and a description of the item(s) requested. A staff member will respond to you with further information.
